entry.title: The Heart of Transformation: People, Process, and Persistence
entry.content:
(Blog 1 of the ‚ÄúTransformation in Field Service‚Äù series)

Introduction

When we hear the word transformation, our minds often jump to technology‚Äîshiny new tools, artificial intelligence, mobile apps, cloud platforms. But in my experience working in Field Service‚Äîand as a parent, gardener, and lifelong learner‚ÄîI‚Äôve found that successful transformation isn‚Äôt just digital.

It‚Äôs deeply human.

The Family Trip That Almost Didn‚Äôt Happen

A few weekends ago, we planned a ‚Äúshort‚Äù hike as a family. With a three-year-old and a four-year-old in tow, I expected some negotiation. One wanted to stay and build a fort in the living room. The other had already left the house wielding a stick like an explorer on a mission. My partner and I were somewhere in the middle‚Äîjuggling snacks, sunhats, and our sanity.

What made the hike possible wasn‚Äôt the gear or the route. It was alignment, motivation, and compromise. We adjusted expectations. Built excitement. Let the kids help plan the snack break. And eventually, we all made it to the top‚Äîtired, proud, and a little muddy.

Honestly? That‚Äôs what transformation looks like.

What It Means for Field Service

The same lessons apply when transforming service operations. You might be rolling out new scheduling software or launching mobile tools for technicians. On paper, the plan looks perfect. But in reality, adoption lags. Resistance creeps in.

Why? Because technology alone doesn‚Äôt change behavior.

Successful transformation requires:

  • People who feel involved, heard, and capable

  • Processes that are redesigned‚Äînot just digitized

  • Persistence to navigate detours, doubts, and delays

üìòWant a model? Try Kotter‚Äôs 8-Step Change Model

Dr. John Kotter‚Äôs framework is widely used in business transformation. It emphasizes:

  1. Creating urgency

  2. Building a guiding coalition

  3. Forming a strategic vision

  4. Enabling action by removing barriers

  5. Celebrating short-term wins

  6. And anchoring the changes in culture

Explore the full model ‚Üí

Technology Is the Enabler, Not the Driver

Tech is powerful. But it‚Äôs like giving my kids high-end hiking gear. If they don‚Äôt know where they‚Äôre going‚Äîor why‚Äîthe gear ends up in the mud.

In Field Service, this means:

  • Involving technicians when introducing mobile apps

  • Listening to dispatchers when reimagining cloud-based workflows

  • Aligning leadership KPIs to real-world service outcomes‚Äînot just feature checklists

üß† Need a practical tool? Consider ADKAR

I have seen companies successfully applying the ADKAR model from Prosci that helps manage individual transitions across 5 stages:

  • Awareness of the need for change

  • Desire to participate in the change

  • Knowledge of how to change

  • Ability to implement change

  • Reinforcement to sustain change

More on ADKAR from Prosci ‚Üí

What‚Äôs Next in This Series

This is the first post in a five-part series exploring key transformations in Field Service:

  • This Part 1: The Heart of Transformation: People, Process, and Persistence

  • Part 2: Embracing AI in Field Service: From Garden Tools to Smart Assistance

  • Part 3: From Paper to Pocket: How Mobile Transformed the Technician‚Äôs Day

  • Part 4: Transitioning to S/4HANA

And throughout: putting people, process, and persistence at the center.

üå±Book tip: Switch: How to Change Things When Change Is Hard

A highly readable book by Chip & Dan Heath, which uses the metaphor of the rider, the elephant, and the path. In Field Service, you often need to steer minds (rider), motivate hearts (elephant), and shape the environment (path).

More on Switch here ‚Üí

entry.title: Custom Widgets in SAP Analytics Cloud - Increased flexibility for Reporting and Planning
entry.content:
What is a SAC Custom Widget? 

The SAP Analytics Cloud offers companies a powerful platform for business intelligence, planning and predictive analyses. SAC provides a large number of standard widgets - so-called basic widgets - with which reports and dashboards can be designed quickly and effectively. Even though these basic widgets cover many common requirements and support a total of 21 different chart types, users sometimes come up against limitations when it comes to more specific visualization requirements. 

This is exactly where custom widgets come into play: these are individually developed visualization elements that go beyond what SAP offers as standard. A SAC custom widget is essentially a web component that consists of a JSON file for the description, JavaScript code for the behavior and optional additional resources such as CSS or images. This allows new chart types as well as customized user interface elements, interactions or even completely new functionalities to be implemented. 

 

GRAPHIC 1: EXAMPLE OF A CUSTOM WIDGET

 

 

Custom widgets offer developers full control: they can design their own diagrams and visualizations from scratch that are perfectly tailored to the specific requirements of a company - be it an interactive network diagram, a dynamic map view or a customized user interface. Thanks to the integration in SAC Stories and the support of the script API, custom widgets fit seamlessly into the existing environment and can be conveniently integrated into Stories via drag & drop. 

Custom widgets therefore allow the SAP Analytics Cloud to be expanded considerably - both in terms of visual design and functional depth. They are the ideal tool if the standard options are not sufficient and the focus is on individual visualization requirements. 

Application scenarios for custom widgets in the SAP Analytics Cloud 

Custom widgets open up a wide range of possible applications in the SAP Analytics Cloud, especially when standard widgets are not sufficient to meet specific requirements. A key area of application is the development of tailor-made visualizations that go beyond the 21 chart types available in the standard system. 

 

GRAPHIC 2: CUSTOM WIDGETS ARE AS INDIVIDUAL AS YOUR COMPANY'S REQUIREMENTS

 

For example, companies can create their own KPI tiles that contain numerical values as well as contextual information such as deviations or trend indicators. In addition, custom widgets enable the integration of interactive user interface elements such as calendars, date pickers or barcode generators that are required in specific business processes. The integration of SAPUI5 controls is also possible, allowing existing components to be reused and complex applications to be implemented efficiently. 

Another scenario is the extension of the SAC functionality by integrating external data sources or APIs. For example, custom widgets can visualize data from third-party systems in real time or enable specific interactions that cannot be realized with standard widgets. This offers companies the flexibility to tailor their dashboards and analyses precisely to their individual needs.  

Overall, custom widgets in the SAP Analytics Cloud offer a powerful way to extend standard functionalities and efficiently implement individual requirements. They are particularly advantageous when specific visualizations, user interactions or data integrations are required that go beyond the standard. 

Custom widgets in detail - how they work in the SAP Analytics Cloud 

Custom widgets can be seamlessly integrated into SAP Analytics Cloud Stories and behave like any other standard widget. After successful deployment, they are automatically listed in the widget menu so that they can be dragged and dropped onto the canvas and placed there. Once inserted, custom widgets can be flexibly moved, resized and visually designed - just like native components in SAC. 

 

GRAPHIC 3: ADD CUSTOM WIDGETS

 

Developers and users benefit from a wide range of functions. Basic properties such as color, font or frame can be adjusted via the styling panel. What is particularly interesting is that in the ‚ÄúAdditional properties‚Äù section, you can add your own options that have been specially defined for the respective custom widget. Additional settings and functions can be stored in the builder panel, for example for data binding or initializing interactions. 

Custom widgets also support direct data binding, which means that they can be connected to data sources - a key requirement for interactive and data-driven visualizations. In the widget structure within a SAC story, custom widgets appear like any other component and can therefore be easily organized and targeted. 

Another powerful feature is the scripting capability: custom widgets can be addressed via the familiar SAC script API. In addition to the methods available as standard, you can also define and implement your own events - such as an onClick that triggers certain actions when the widget is clicked. This flexibility makes Custom Widgets a versatile tool that can be deeply integrated into SAC, both visually and functionally. 

Technical requirements and authorizations 

The development and use of custom widgets in the SAP Analytics Cloud requires specific technical prerequisites and authorizations. By default, SAP roles are restricted to read access. To create or update custom widgets, users must be assigned additional authorizations. These authorizations can either be set globally for all custom widgets or individually per widget. In particular, widget designers require the rights to create and update widgets. 

Several files are required to create a custom widget, including a JSON file to define the metadata and a JavaScript file for the functionality. These files are packed into a ZIP file together with optional resources such as CSS files or images. This ZIP file is then uploaded directly to the SAC, eliminating the need for external hosting. 

The development environment for custom widgets includes tools such as Visual Studio Code, a free editor from Microsoft that is particularly suitable for editing HTML and JavaScript. To create complex charts, developers can integrate free chart libraries such as ECharts, D3.js or Chart.js to realize advanced visualization options. 

 

GRAPHIC 4: DEVELOPMENT ENVIRONMENT

 

However, there are currently certain limitations when using custom widgets. For example, only Chromium-based browsers such as Google Chrome and Microsoft Edge are fully supported. In addition, the number of custom widgets that can be loaded into a single SAC tenant is limited to 50. 

Some features of the SAC are not supported by custom widgets. These include themes and CSS adjustments, pause refresh, commenting, scheduling, translations, data change insights and the ‚ÄúSearch to Insight‚Äù function. Restrictions may also occur when exporting custom widgets to PDF, especially if certain chart libraries such as D3.js are used or if CSS settings are defined in the widget. 

There are numerous examples for references in the SAP Community and in SAP Help: 

  • SAP Analytics Cloud Custom Widget Developer Guide 
  • SAP Custom Widget examples on GitHub 
  • SAP Technology Blog: Custom Widgets & Widget Add-Ons 
  • Echarts library examples 
  • SAP Analytics Cloud Widget Add-On Developer Guide 
     

Your path to SAP Analytics Cloud Custom Widgets 

The introduction of custom widgets in the SAP Analytics Cloud offers companies an outstanding opportunity to expand their analytics solutions individually and to tailor them visually and functionally to specific requirements. To maximize the benefits, we recommend a structured and proven approach. 

  1. requirements analysis: In initial workshops, we work with you to analyze the technical, functional and content requirements for the planned custom widget. In this way, we ensure that all stakeholder needs are understood and taken into account - from IT to the specialist department. 
  2. proof of concept: We then develop an initial minimum viable product (MVP) to demonstrate the technical feasibility. This PoC serves as the basis for further decisions and for internal coordination with relevant teams. 
  3. implementation: Based on the PoC, we add the required functionalities to the widget, test it in your SAC environment and hand over the finished custom widget as part of a clean documentation and handover. 
  4.  

GRAPHIC 5: EVALUATION

 

Custom widgets are a modular building block for making a variety of advanced functions usable in SAC - from individual visualizations to complex interactions. They promote acceptance among end users and enable customized solutions for company-specific challenges. At the same time, you should consider the increased development effort compared to standard widgets and the possible training requirements for your team - because individual developments also require internal know-how in the long term.

The Below is the Sample payload that I considered to work on.

<Products>

        <ProductID>P1001</ProductID>
        <ProductName>Wireless Mouse</ProductName>
        <Category>Electronics</Category>
        <Price>25.99</Price>

        <StockQuantity>150</StockQuantity>
        <UnitOfMeasure>EA</UnitOfMeasure>
        <Supplier>LogiTech Inc.</Supplier>
    </Product>
 </Products>


The below snippet is a Groovy script used for dynamic routing . It reads the root tag from the XML payload and sets the route name in the property routeTo based on the tag value. 

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import groovy.util.XmlSlurper

Message processData(Message message) {
    def body = message.getBody(String) // Get XML as a string
    def xml = new XmlSlurper().parseText(body) // Parse XML

    def targetRoute = ""

    // Check the root element or a specific tag (adjust as needed)
    if (xml.name() == "Products") {
        targetRoute = "publisher_solace_inbound_products_layer-2"
    } else if (xml.name() == "Suppliers") {
        targetRoute = "publisher_solace_inbound_suppliers_layer_2"
    } else {
        targetRoute = "publisher_solace_inbound_books_layer_2"
    }

    message.setProperty("routeTo", targetRoute) // Store the route in a property
    return message
}

As the Above sample data belongs to Products, so it will be dynamically routed to the corresponding Products transaction layer.

So, AEM (Advanced event mesh)  acts as an adapter between SAP CPI and the Solace Event Broker, enabling seamless event-based communication.

entry.title: Connect to Public Cloud API in Node.js via Authorisation Code
entry.content:
Connecting to a Public Cloud API (from Business Accelerator Hub) via Node.js CAP application can be challenging. I hope this blog helps others attempting the same task.

 Prerequisites

‚Ä¢ SAP BTP subaccount (Cloud Foundry)
‚Ä¢ Service key for the target Public Cloud API
‚Ä¢ XSUAA instance bound to your CAP app
‚Ä¢ SAP BTP Destination service instance
‚Ä¢ Bruno installed for manual testing

 

1. Confirm the API's Auth Options

First, check which authentication methods are available for the API you plan to consume.

In my example I connect to the Specification Management API, but the steps apply to any Public Cloud API.

If the OAuth 2.0 Access Code Flow is listed under ‚ÄúAuthentication Methods‚Äù, the API supports the authorization-code flow. That flow confirms a user context and usually grants wider authorisations, such as update and POST requests.

(OAuth 2.0 Application Flow corresponds to the client-credentials flow.)

2. Connect manually with Bruno (Good blog on Bruno)

Because our API supports the auth-code flow, we first prove we can log in by calling it via Bruno.

Create a new collection and paste the base URI of your Public Cloud API instance (you‚Äôll find it in the service key in your service instance of the saas application your connecting to).

When you send a test GET request you will probably receive an authorisation error. Configure OAuth 2.0 on the Auth tab

Select Grant type Authorisation Code

Then fill in the below fields using your service key from your service instance

  • Callback URL: <your Public Cloud API hostname>
  • Auth URL:** https://<subdomain>.authentication.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/authorize
  • Access-Token URL: https://<subdomain>.authentication.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token
  • Client ID / Secret: from the uaa section of the service key

Request the token, pick your identity provider, and Bruno will return an access token. Inspect the scopes there to see what you can do.

3. Connect to the API from Node.js

After the manual check we can now automate the flow in a Node.js service.

3.1 Destination setup

Create a destination that points to the same API endpoint and bind it to your app.

The required scopes and the audience (aud) value are visible inside the Bruno access token.

the Audience should start with the client id of your CAP application on BTP

Once the destination is saved, ensure your application is bound to the Destination service.

3.2 xs-security.json

Add every scope your service needs so the approuter, it will forward it in the user‚Äôs JWT: in my example i needed this scope.

{
  "name": "$XSAPPNAME.Spc_Write",
  "description": "Allow modification of specifications."
}

Also reference the scope in authorities (and role templates, if used) and assign the resulting role collection to your user.

3.3 Connect in code

Now time to connect to the API in the code itself.

First, obtain the user‚Äôs JWT. This helper below tries every possible source and falls back to LOCAL_USER_JWT in local development:

/** Try every source for a JWT and fall back to LOCAL_USER_JWT. */
function getJwt(capReq) {
  // CAP ‚â• 7.3 keeps the raw token here
  if (capReq.user?.jwt) return capReq.user.jwt;

  // Plain HTTP / WebSocket headers
  const hdrs = capReq.http?.req?.headers || {};
  const token =
        hdrs['x-approuter-authorization'] ||   // CF WebSocket
        hdrs.authorization;                    // CF HTTP

  if (token) return token.replace(/^Bearer\s+/, '');
  // Last resort for local dev
  return process.env.LOCAL_USER_JWT;
}

3.3.1 Testing locally

When testing locally we don't have access to the user JWT so we can add it manually to the environment file so we can still test locally, below is the process to get the JWT for user testing (each token lasts about 7 to 8 hours)

Step 1 ‚Äì Get an auth code
https://<instance>.eu10.authentication.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/authorize
?response_type=code
&client_id=<XSUAA client id of your deployed app>
&redirect_uri=http://localhost
&state=xyz

Paste your version into your browsers address bar, after login you will land on http://localhost/?code=<AUTH_CODE>&state=xyz. Copy the value of AUTH_CODE.

Step 2 ‚Äì Exchange the code for a JWT

I made the Curl Request inside BAS itself. it will return a number of tokens, we only need the first and biggest one.

curl -v -X POST \
-u '<same client id>' \
--data-urlencode grant_type=authorization_code \
--data-urlencode code=<AUTH_CODE> \
--data-urlencode redirect_uri=http://localhost \
https://<instance>.eu10.authentication.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token

Save the token from the response into .env:

LOCAL_USER_JWT=<paste JWT here>

3.3.2 Call the destination with the JWT

const jwt = getJwt(req);
if (!jwt) req.reject(401, 'No user token found.');

const dest = await getDestination({
  destinationName: '<DestinationName>',
  jwt
});
await executeHttpRequest(dest, {
  method: 'POST',
  url: `/odata/v4/api/specification/v1/${EntityName}`,
  data: v
});

If you reach the destination but receive 401 Unauthorized, your JWT is missing the correct scope‚Äîask the product team which one you need.

Other common pitfall is using the different XSUAA instances to get your JWT for the local run. use your applications XSUAA client since this is the same one your application will check the token against

And that‚Äôs it! You should now be able to read from and write to the Public Cloud API. For read-only workloads the client-credentials flow is usually simpler.

If I missed anything or you‚Äôd like more details, please comment below‚Äîhappy to help.

 

## Frequently Asked Questions

### What‚Äôs the difference between authorization-code and client-credentials flows?
The authorization-code flow runs in a user context, so it can carry user-level scopes (read, write, update). The client-credentials flow operates with a technical user‚Äîperfect for background jobs or read-only integrations.

### Why do I get ‚Äú401 Unauthorized‚Äù after deployment?
Your user‚Äôs JWT is probably missing the required scope (e.g., `Spc_Write`). Make sure the scope is listed in xs-security.json, mapped to a role template, and assigned via a role collection in the BTP cockpit.

### Which audience value belongs in my destination?
Use the client ID of your CAP application‚Äôs XSUAA instance; it usually starts with `sb-<appName>!t<number>`.

entry.title: Webcast Series: SAP's Four-Part Journey Through Architecting Modern SAP Landscapes
entry.content:
In an era where digital transformation has evolved from competitive advantage to survival imperative, enterprise architects find themselves at the crossroads of unprecedented technological convergence. The traditional boundaries between artificial intelligence, cloud platforms, and business applications are dissolving, creating both immense opportunities and complex architectural challenges. To address this shifting landscape, SAP‚Äôs global Enterprise Architecture & Advisory team recently delivered a four-part webcast series that charts a course through the most pressing architectural questions facing organizations today.

This series, "Enterprise Architecture for Modern SAP Landscapes," was developed at the invitation of the broader "Move to Cloud ERP" webcast series, powered by the SAP Global User Groups Organization to serve the worldwide SAP community."

It represents more than just technical guidance‚Äîit's a strategic roadmap for navigating the fundamental transformation of how businesses architect, deploy, and govern their technology ecosystems. From debunking persistent myths that paralyze decision-making to realizing the promise of clean core principles, each session builds upon the others to create a holistic view of modern enterprise architecture, delivering the practical insights that user groups across the globe have been requesting for their digital transformation journeys.

 

Part 1: Debunking Enterprise Architecture Myths

Date: June 10, 2025 | Speaker: Dr. Michael Blaschke (@Michael_Blaschke), Enterprise Architect, SAP

The series opens with perhaps the most critical challenge facing enterprise architects today: separating fact from fiction in SAP‚Äôs modern architecture paradigms. The opening session, ‚ÄúDebunking Enterprise Architecture Myths: Clean Core, SAP S/4HANA, and BTP,‚Äù tackles seven persistent misconceptions that continue to derail digital transformation initiatives across organizations.

These aren‚Äôt merely technical misunderstandings‚Äîthey‚Äôre strategic barriers that cost organizations millions in project delays and suboptimal architectural decisions. The session demonstrates how clean core principles extend far beyond SAP S/4HANA implementation, enabling strategic custom development while maintaining upgrade safety and innovation velocity. Through architectural patterns and real-world case studies, attendees learn to counter myths with evidence-based approaches that accelerate rather than impede transformation.

What makes this session particularly valuable is its focus on communication and stakeholder management. Enterprise architects often find themselves in the unenviable position of defending architectural decisions against deeply held misconceptions. This presentation equips them with the truths and techniques needed to lead evidence-based discussions in executive steering committees.

Download PDF | Watch Replay

 

Part 2: Architecting Innovation-Platform Ecosystems

Date: June 17, 2025 | Speaker: Dr. Michael Blaschke (@Michael_Blaschke), Enterprise Architect, SAP

The second installment shifts focus to one of the most significant architectural transformations of our time: the evolution from traditional product-platform ecosystems to dynamic innovation-platform ecosystems. ‚ÄúEnterprise Architecture for Transitioning from Product-platform to Innovation-platform Ecosystems‚Äù explores how enterprise architects can design the foundational layers necessary for fostering co-creation and external innovation.

This session is grounded in rigorous academic research by @Michael_Blaschke, drawing from his peer-reviewed studies on platform ecosystem dynamics and digital transformation patterns. The presentation unveils the architectural building blocks required to create open, scalable innovation-platform ecosystems that support API-first strategies and platform economics while maintaining essential governance and security controls.

The transition from product-platform to innovation-platform ecosystems represents a fundamental shift in how organizations create and capture value. Enterprise architects learn to design the organizational capabilities that enable ecosystem participation, support multi-sided marketplace dynamics, and unlock network effects‚Äîall while ensuring the organization doesn‚Äôt sacrifice operational stability for innovation velocity.

Download PDF | Watch Replay

Supporting Research:

  • Dynamic capabilities for transitioning from product platform ecosystem to innovation platform ecosystem
  • Capabilities for Digital Platform Survival: Insights from a Business-to-Business Digital Platform

entry.title: Understanding the Distinct Scope of SAP Cloud ERP Private
entry.content:
As organisations evaluate deployment options for their ERP systems, SAP Cloud ERP Private are often compared without taking the full scope of services into account. Yet, its unique architecture and comprehensive service model make direct comparisons challenging - and frequently misleading.

Traditional comparisons tend to overlook many of the embedded services that come standard with SAP Cloud ERP Private and ignore many of the available options, inadvertently giving other deployment models an apparent advantage. This not only skews perception but also obscures the full value SAP delivers out of the box.

To bring clarity to this discussion, we highlight the key services included in SAP Cloud ERP Private. Our goal is to empower customers with a clear understanding of what they receive, helping them make informed decisions based on a complete picture.

Modernise your ERP system while retaining your investment

SAP aims to transition all customers using SAP ERP to SAP S/4HANA by 2027. Before the introduction of RISE with SAP in 2021, SAP did not fully meet the needs of customers seeking cloud-based ERP solutions. The primary option available was S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, which required a new implementation. This was not a viable option for many existing SAP ERP customers who wanted to retain their investment in their current systems, leverage existing data, and carry forward customizations and modifications.

To address this gap, SAP introduced SAP Cloud ERP Private solutions with the launch of RISE with SAP. These single-tenant solutions offer each customer their own dedicated instance of SAP software, hosted on separate infrastructure within a data center operated by one of the major hyperscalers or SAP itself. Existing SAP ERP customers can choose to either lift-and-shift their SAP ERP systems or transition to SAP Cloud ERP Private using a system conversion, selective data transition, or a new implementation approach.

With SAP Cloud ERP Private, SAP is taking away the complexity of designing, building and operating SAP software for our customers. We're doing this by providing a user or metric-based subscription model that includes the software and tooling license, infrastructure and technical managed services - everything that you need to run an SAP solution.

SAP Design, Build and Operate the entire SAP technical solution stack

SAP Enterprise Cloud Services (ECS), the business unit in SAP who is responsible for design, build and operate of Cloud ERP Private, delivers a robust framework for operating SAP Cloud ERP Private solutions, combining infrastructure, software licensing, and technical managed services into a unified subscription model. This approach simplifies the complexity of running SAP systems in a private cloud while ensuring enterprise-grade performance, security, and compliance.

SAP ECS invests heavily in capabilities that ensure robust system design, rapid setup and delivery, and a high degree of automation for operational tasks. This section outlines the key activities performed by SAP ECS, categorized into three phases - Design, Build, and Operate.

The diagram below highlights the key cost elements covered in SAP Cloud ERP Private for the design, build and operation of SAP, while customers retain the responsibility and control of the application layer throughout the three phases. This is valid for every implementation and every time technical changes are made to the SAP system landscape, reducing technical tasks for customers so they can focus more on the business:

The SAP Cloud ERP Private service cover key cost elements for the setup and operation of SAP

The process of designing, building and operating SAP requires broad areas of technical expert competence and requires answers to many detailed technical questions necessary to make strong architecture design decisions. In SAP Cloud ERP Private, this complexity is moved away from being a customer responsibility to the responsibility of SAP and SAP will have the answers during the design, build and operate phases.

1. Design Phase

The primary goal of the Design phase activities is to define standard and configurable cloud-based architectures for SAP ERP systems that enable rapid deployment, customer choice to cater to their unique requirements and minimum manual overhead while meeting SAP‚Äôs stringent availability, Recovery Time Objective (RTO), and Recovery Point Objective (RPO), Service Level Agreements (SLAs), security and compliance standards. SAP ECS periodically reviews and refines these architectures and operational processes considering improvements in Hyperscaler infrastructure capabilities, 3rd party tools and services and SAP ECS‚Äôs own operational experience.

There are several complex topics that need to be addressed during this phase:

  • Which hyperscaler building blocks to use?
  • Which virtual machine instances are the right fit and certified by SAP?
  • What is the security design?
  • How can business continuity be achieved?
  • How should the systems be monitored?
  • How can resources be effectively scaled?
  • What is the architecture design?

Key activities performed by SAP ECS as part of the Design phase:

  • Reference Architectures: SAP collaborates with hyperscalers to define scalable, secure cloud architectures using SAP best practices.
  • Security & Compliance: Network isolation, encryption, intrusion detection, and adherence to ISO/NIST standards.
  • Monitoring & Incident Response System: Proactive incident response systems and tailored architecture advisory services ensure resilience and performance.
  • Cloud Architecture & Advisory: SAP collaborates with customers to define optimal technical architecture, considering each customer‚Äôs system sizing, cloud security, networking and technical integration, and business continuity requirements. SAP and customers jointly engage in a Technical Assessment process to ensure the non-functional requirements are met in SAP Cloud ERP Private.

For every SAP ERP customer moving to SAP Cloud ERP Private solutions, an SAP advisory team which is part of ECS (SAP Cloud Architecture & Advisory (CAA) which provides the above Cloud Architecture & Advisory services) or a similar partner advisory team, analyzes customer requirements and determines the best suitable configuration for the customer. By leveraging pre-defined standard and configurable cloud-based architectures defined by SAP, the time taken to define the architectures for each customer is significantly reduced and the decision process is simplified.

2. Build Phase

The primary goal of the Build phase activities is to define how to install, configure and validate the systems
that have been designed. There are several complex topics that need to be addressed during this phase:

  • Which tools should be used?
  • How to ensure systems are built to provide optimal performance?
  • How to migrate existing workloads?
  • How to ensure implementation best practices are followed?
  • How to reduce the deployment time?
  • How to technically validate the new infrastructure?
  • How to ensure proper governance to manage issues?

SAP has created a global framework for the build phase that spans the multi-cloud Infrastructure ecosystem.
This framework covers best practices for migration into the cloud, automated provisioning, deployment, and
validation of SAP systems. This allows our customers to safely adopt and run new SAP software innovations
because cloud services are tested and made production-ready before they are made available to customers.

  • Datacenter facilities, physical hardware and connectivity
  • Infrastructure Provisioning: Certified compute, storage, and network components are deployed using automated tools and DevOps methodologies.
  • Technical Managed Services required to build and deliver the infrastructure
  • Software Stack: SAP installs and configures OS, databases, and ERP applications, including industry best practices.
  • Operational Tooling: Licensing and integration of provisioning, monitoring, backup, and cybersecurity tools.

3. Operate Phase

The primary goal of the operate phase is to provide ongoing support, infrastructure management, change
management and the technical services necessary to run the application. There are several complex topics
that need to be addressed during this phase:

  • How should the SLAs be measured?
  • How to manage the changes?
  • How to automate and achieve operational efficiency?
  • How to manage security incidents and threats?
  • How to keep SAP applications up-to-date?
  • How to address capacity planning?

SAP Enterprise Cloud Services accelerates and simplifies customers‚Äô business transformation by running their SAP systems with a world-class level of availability, security and resilience, supported by an application-level SLA and a managed cloud service tailored to SAP systems. After a successful transition from the build phase to the operate phase, the ongoing support work is performed, along with additional application deployment activities. It covers the management of the installed infrastructure and applications, scaling the infrastructure, and managing ITIL processes through an engagement model with proven governance to secure business continuity.

  • Datacenter & Capacity Management: Continuous infrastructure optimization, backup integrity, and disaster recovery planning.
  • Security Operations: 24/7 threat detection, patching, vulnerability scanning, and advanced forensics.
  • Service Management: ITIL-based workflows, global support teams, and dedicated technical service managers ensure SLA adherence and business continuity.

Selecting the right deployment for your ERP system

Through SAP's Technical Assessment process, we work closely with each customer to address all questions related to the design, build, and operation of SAP in Cloud ERP Private. During this assessment, SAP provides detailed insights into the cloud service elements and explains the available options for transitioning to SAP Cloud ERP Private.

One such option is SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper, which helps customers extend support for their existing S/4HANA systems, ensuring business continuity: Bridging the gap with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Safekeeper

SAP ECS empowers enterprises to move legacy ERP systems to private cloud environments without compromising control, compliance, or customisation. Our private cloud strategy serves as a blueprint for scalable, secure, and intelligent ERP modernisation.

entry.title: Linux Shell Script for automating graceful startup and shutdown of SAP S4HANA System
entry.content:
Linux Shell Script for automating graceful startup and shutdown of SAP S4HANA [Only meant for Single Tier System] in SUSE Linux VMs/Instances inside cloud environment.

 

This post is purely focusing on the OS level scripting and is not associated with nor related with any of the cloud console level automation using serverless concepts, for example AWS Lambda.

 

Running SAP S4HANA on virtual machines in cloud environments like Azure, AWS, or Google Cloud comes with its unique challenges‚Äîespecially when it comes to starting and stopping services reliably and cost-effectively.

 

As most of us are familiar, when a VM or Instance boots up, post the OS booting process, it‚Äôs critical to start the SAP HANA database *before* the SAP application to avoid issues/failures. Similarly, during a VM shutdown, the SAP application must stop *before* the database to ensure all processes close gracefully, preventing data corruption or downtime.

 

Leaving SAP systems running idle can also cause unnecessary cloud billing, especially in PoC or Demo setups where uptime directly impacts costs.

 

To address the above mentioned two of the key issues, I developed simple yet effective shell scripts that automate the controlled start and stop sequence of SAP S4HANA based on the VM‚Äôs lifecycle. These scripts can be manually invoked or integrated into cloud startup/shutdown hooks, ensuring SAP services respond correctly whenever the OS boots or halts.

 

This automation enhances reliability and saves effort and rework by enabling the graceful shutting down of SAP S4HANA App and DB.

 

Here‚Äôs how it works:

To achieve the above-mentioned automation, you need to follow the steps mentioned below

 

  1.       Logon with root user on the VM/instance where SAP DB & Application is hosted.
  2.       Gain the clean root environment with default variables and path using the command: sudo su -
  3.       Navigate to the path: /etc/systemd/system/
  4.       vi sap-s4hana.service
  5.       enter the following contents in this file.

Note: Please refer to the path used in this file content, you need to use same or in case you want to change the path or file naming convention etc., you may document the changes accordingly.

 

[Unit]

Description=SAP S/4HANA single-tier startup/shutdown orchestrator (HANA + App)

After=network.target

 

[Service]

Type=oneshot

ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/sap-start.sh

ExecStop=/usr/local/bin/sap-stop.sh

RemainAfterExit=yes

TimeoutStartSec=1800

TimeoutStopSec=1800

 

[Install]

WantedBy=multi-user.target

 

  1.       save the file
  2.       Update the permissions of this file: chmod +x sap-s4hana.service
  3.       Update file ownership of this file: chown root:root sap-s4hana.service
  4.       For creating the shell script for starting the SAP S4HANA DB and SAP S4 Application, Navigate to the path:

/usr/local/bin

vi sap-start.sh

  1. 10.  enter the following contents in this file:

Note: Please refer to the path used in this file content, you need to use same or in case you want to change the path or naming convention, you may document the changes accordingly.

Ensure to update the relevant user id, SAP SID, Instance Numbers in this content,

entry.title: Sizing Your Success: A Guide to SAP Cloud ERP Private
entry.content:
From my perspective, effective sizing is one of the most underestimated yet critical aspects of any SAP transformation. While SAP offers a standardized and well-defined architecture, every customer‚Äôs landscape, data footprint, and performance expectations are unique. This makes it essential for customers and their implementation partners to take ownership of sizing, validation, and optimization activities.

For SAP customers, partners, and technical teams navigating the shift to SAP S/4HANA and other solutions within SAP Cloud ERP Private, accurate system sizing is paramount. While SAP provides a globally consistent, standardized architecture, the responsibility for executing and validating sizing activities rests squarely with the customer and their implementation partners.

Ultimately, accurate sizing isn‚Äôt just a technical exercise; it‚Äôs a strategic enabler for stability, scalability, and long-term cost efficiency.

This guide demystifies SAP sizing, focusing on the core concepts, benefits, and practical methods within the SAP Cloud ERP Private landscape.

What is SAP Cloud ERP Private?

SAP Cloud ERP Private is a cloud-based offering that marries the control of an on-premise system with the agility and efficiency of the cloud. It guides customers toward a clean core through standardized processes and modern extensibility via SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), and in-app extensibility tools.

I think the biggest advantage of running SAP on certified cloud infrastructure that SAP Cloud ERP Private oferring adheres to is how it simplifies everything ‚Äî security, compliance, and support are all built in. It lets IT teams spend less time keeping the lights on and more time driving innovation. The key, though, is being ready to fully embrace the cloud mindset to get the most out of it.

For more information please refer to Understanding the Distinct Scope of SAP Cloud ERP Private.

General SAP Sizing Overview

SAP sizing is the process of precisely determining the required hardware resources such as CPU, memory, storage, and network capacity to effectively support an SAP system based on specific business needs. It‚Äôs a blend of science, utilizing tools and calculations, and expert judgment to account for the unique context of each implementation.

Key aspects of sizing include:

  • Translating Business Requirements: Starting with user counts, transaction volumes, data growth, and performance expectations.
  • Hardware Determination: Calculating the required compute, memory, and storage.
  • Iterative Process: Sizing isn't a one-time event. It must be revisited as the business and technology evolve. This is because sizing relies on assumptions and approximations about future usage, and it must balance optimal performance with cost management.
  • Data Quality is Critical: The accuracy of the sizing results is heavily dependent on the quality of the validated usage data and sizing assumptions provided by customers and partners.

SAP Cloud ERP Private Sizing Strategy

Sizing for SAP Cloud ERP Private is a vital step to ensure your infrastructure efficiently supports your SAP workloads. SAP offers two primary models:

  1. Standard Sizing: A simplified, consumption-based model using predefined T-shirt size service bundles (e.g., XXS to 4XL), which provides a baseline scope with a minimal sizing effort.
  2. Tailored Sizing: A more granular, customized approach for complex landscapes, offering greater flexibility based on detailed requirements.

Key Sizing Steps

A structured approach to sizing includes:

  • Define the Scope: Identify the SAP applications (e.g., SAP S/4HANA, SAP BW/4HANA) and specific modules, determine transaction workloads, and define usage (e.g., Production, QA).
  • Collect Baseline Data: Use tools like the SAP Quick Sizer for new systems or EarlyWatch Reports and historical data (ST03N / ST06) for existing ones. For migrations, the SAP Readiness Check is essential.
  • Use SAP Sizing Tools: Leverage tools like Quick Sizer (greenfield) or specific sizing reports like /SDF/HDB_SIZING (brownfield) to get technical resource estimates.
  • Incorporate Growth & Buffer: Always plan for projected growth (3‚Äì5 years) and add a buffer (typically 10‚Äì25%) for peak loads and future needs.
  • Validate with Experts: Review and validate sizing with SAP experts, potentially via a "Size to Scale" engagement through SAP Premium Engagement.

Standard Sizing: The T-Shirt Model

The Standard approach maps your business needs to a predefined, T-shirt-sized model.

Tailored Sizing: Customization for Complexity

The Tailored Option provides granular control and customized hardware specifications. This model combines standard tools with deep expert analysis, allowing more precise control over application server sizing and high-availability (HA)/disaster-recovery (DR) configurations.

‚ÄúSize to Scale‚Äù and Technical Assessment

The SAP Cloud ERP Private Technical Assessment is a mandatory, comprehensive evaluation designed to analyze and document the technical requirements, architecture, and sizing needs.

SAP Expert Sizing Engagement

For complex, large, or unusual landscapes, engaging an SAP expert is highly recommended. The "Size to Scale" is the expert sizing service from SAP offered via SAP Premium Engagements (MaxAttention or ActiveAttention). It provides a deep-dive, tailored sizing service.

When is "Size to Scale" required?

SAP proactively escalates an implementation for expert review if:

  • Initial analysis indicates a SAP HANA DB Requirement > 4 TiB.
  • A large amount of custom code is being migrated.
  • There are plans to consolidate multiple ERP solutions or significant new functionality (e.g., embedded EWM/TM).

SAP Sizing & Technical Assessment Engagement Flow

The sizing process is a multi-step flow involving different teams:

  1. Initiation & Scoping: Define objectives and scope with Customer, SAP Account Executives, and SAP Cloud Architecture & Advisory (CAA).
  2. Data Collection & Pre-Assessment: Customer and partner run sizing reports (e.g., /SDF/HDB_SIZING, SAP Readiness Check) and collect historical performance data.
  3. Sizing Analysis: The SAP CAA team analyzes data, maps it to infrastructure (T-shirt or tailored specs), and applies the necessary growth buffer.
  4. Technical Assessment Review & Validation: Finalized sizing assumptions are reviewed, aligned on HA/DR/network, documented in the Technical Assessment Report, and signed off by the customer.
  5. Handover to Delivery: The infrastructure is provisioned as per the agreed specifications.

Monitoring and Reporting in Cloud ERP, Private

After provisioning, continuous monitoring is key to validating the sizing and ensuring performance. This is managed through core services provided as part of the SAP Cloud ERP Private offering:

  • Capacity Management: This ongoing process ensures the environment meets performance and availability requirements by monitoring utilization, forecasting demand, and dynamically adjusting resource allocation.
  • Problem Management: This function identifies, analyzes, and resolves capacity and performance issues. It links directly back to sizing by investigating if initial assumptions were inaccurate and recommending a necessary resizing or optimization.
  • Performance Benchmarking (Enhanced Operations Services for Large Enterprises ‚Äì EOS LE): A jointly defined service that measures selected business transactions over time, helping to identify performance trends and proactively mitigate future issues. 

    For more information on EOS LE please refer to SAP Cloud ERP, Private Service Description site.

By diligently performing and validating your sizing assumptions, your organization can ensure that your SAP S/4HANA journey in SAP Cloud ERP Private is built on a foundation of optimal performance, scalability, and cost efficiency.

Greenfield vs. Brownfield: Sizing Strategies for SAP S/4HANA Success

When moving to SAP S/4HANA, especially within the SAP Cloud ERP Private environment, the path you choose dictates your sizing strategy. Do you start fresh (greenfield) or convert an existing system (brownfield)?

While both methods rely on core SAP sizing tools, the inputs, assumptions, and required infrastructure for CPU, RAM, and storage diverge significantly. Understanding these differences is crucial for accurate provisioning and avoiding costly over- or under-sizing.

Greenfield Sizing: Building from the Blueprint

Use Case: A new SAP S/4HANA system deployment, often involving redefined, standardized business processes and a selective data migration.

Key Considerations:

  • Reliance on SAP Quick Sizer: Since no historical data exists, sizing is purely business-driven. You input future metrics like the number of users by type, sales order volumes, and financial transaction counts. The Quick Sizer outputs estimates for SAP HANA memory, CPU cores, and disk sizes.
  • Reduced Data Footprint: Greenfield often means selective data migration (e.g., only the last 2‚Äì3 years of transactional history). This results in a smaller initial database, lower storage requirements, and reduced initial RAM needs.
  • Cleaner Architecture: With fewer customizations and a focus on standard SAP S/4HANA processes, sizing for application performance is more predictable.
  • Add a Growth Buffer: As with any new implementation, add a significant buffer (typically ~20‚Äì30%) to account for future data growth, unforeseen business process changes, or new functionality adoption.

Brownfield Sizing: Converting the Past to the Future

Use Case: Converting an existing SAP ECC or SAP S/4HANA system to the private cloud, retaining existing processes and full data history.

Key Considerations:

  • Historical Data Analysis is Key: Sizing is usage-based. You must analyze the current system's historical performance to get an accurate estimate.
    • Workload Analysis: Use ST03N (workload analysis) and ST06 (system resources) data, and EarlyWatch Reports to understand CPU and memory utilization patterns.
    • Data Archiving is Best Practice: To optimize your sizing, archive and clean up unnecessary data before running the sizing reports.
  • The Crucial Sizing Report: The primary tool is the SAP HANA Sizing Report (/SDF/HDB_SIZING), detailed in SAP Note 1872170. This report runs on your existing system to analyze current database size, compression factors, and transaction volumes, providing a precise estimate of the required SAP HANA memory.
  • Accounting for Custom Code: Custom programs and reports (often numerous in an SAP ECC system) require assessment. The Custom Code Analyzer helps evaluate their impact, as unoptimized custom code can significantly increase required CPU and RAM.
  • Include Conversion Load: Be aware that the migration itself requires a temporary sizing uplift for staging, code remediation, and data transformation activities.

entry.title: SAP Landscape Strategy in the Era of Managed Cloud and AI
entry.content:
In today‚Äôs digital-first world, enterprises face intense pressure to operate faster, leaner, and smarter. Emerging technologies like cloud computing, AI, and next-generation ERP systems are transforming how businesses run. Amid this change, SAP landscape consolidation presents a complex challenge, requiring close alignment between business and IT. While it can simplify IT environments, reduce costs, and enable intelligent automation, many organizations struggle to find the right approach. This article aims to demystify the topic, offering executives a clear framework to evaluate options, make informed decisions, and maximize value through an effective instance strategy.

The Case for Landscape Consolidation

Historically, most organizations have accumulated fragmented SAP landscapes through mergers, acquisitions, and regional growth‚Äîeach business unit running its own version of ‚Äúthe truth.‚Äù These siloed environments inflate total cost of ownership, complicate reporting, and slow decision-making. Consolidation directly addresses this by unifying systems into a single, standardized architecture that delivers agility, transparency, and control. From the 1990s to the 2000s, technological limits‚Äîparticularly hardware capacity‚Äîonce made global system consolidation impractical. But today, with exponential advancements in computing power, cloud scalability, and tools like SAP‚Äôs Unicode-based Business Suite and Country Versions, technology is no longer the barrier. The question is no longer can we consolidate, but why haven‚Äôt we yet?

The financial argument is equally compelling. Organizations that have consolidated SAP landscapes typically achieve measurable cost reductions across key operational areas‚Äîaround 20% in IT operations, 15% in end-user services, 10% in application development, and 8% in maintenance and administration. These savings compound over time, freeing up capital for innovation and strategic growth. More importantly, a unified system landscape enhances global visibility, and accelerates decision-making at scale. For CIOs and CFOs alike, landscape consolidation is not merely an IT optimization‚Äîit‚Äôs a business transformation lever that drives sustainable efficiency, competitive advantage, and enterprise-wide value creation.

Beyond Systems: Why Process Harmonization Matters

System consolidation alone doesn‚Äôt guarantee efficiency. Without harmonized business processes, organizations often find that operational inconsistencies persist even after technical consolidation is achieved. In other words, system consolidation without process harmonization is suboptimal from a total cost of ownership (TCO) perspective.

According to SAP Value Group benchmarks, the typical cost distribution for enterprise systems is approximately 20% hardware, 20% software, 42% development, application support, help desk, and end-user training, 12% system and data management, and 8% other. The largest cost category ‚Äî development and support ‚Äî can only be reduced when process variants and customizations are minimized through harmonization and standardization. For this reason, almost all companies that embark on global implementation or consolidation programs also pursue global harmonization of their business processes.

However, while IT organizations often recognize the benefits of harmonization and may attempt to implement global templates ‚Äúbehind the scenes,‚Äù true process harmonization cannot be successfully driven by IT alone. It is not a one-time technical exercise, but a continuous business-led transformation that requires executive sponsorship, strong governance, and a clear change management strategy. The business must own and drive harmonization initiatives, defining clear objectives that align with organizational strategy. When processes are harmonized, they enable consistent data, standardized workflows, and measurable outcomes ‚Äî all of which are essential foundations for scaling intelligent automation and realizing the full efficiency potential of system consolidation.

Ultimately, while IT cost savings from ERP instance consolidation may reach 25%, the true value lies in achieving global visibility, standardized processes, and improved business coordination‚Äîbenefits attainable only when system consolidation is paired with process harmonization.

How Cloud & AI Have Evolved SAP Landscape Strategy

SAP has long been at the forefront of enterprise transformation. At the core of this evolution is a shift in how enterprises view their landscapes ‚Äî not just as technical environments but as strategic enablers. The pyramid structure in the diagram below highlights how harmonization and standardization at the strategic level (vision, strategy, and processes) are driving the reduction of system complexity at the operational level (infrastructure and projects). This reflects SAP‚Äôs broader goal: simplifying, standardizing, and automating across every layer of the enterprise stack.

The right side of the diagram captures how landscape simplification and consolidation have evolved in a cloud-first era. Hyperscalers have made on-premise (non-SAP managed) operations more flexible and efficient; however, the cost advantages of cloud operations are making regional or local systems increasingly attractive. At the same time, geopolitical disruptions and growing requirements for data localization are prompting enterprises to reconsider their global architectures. As business units evolve, organizations need modular IT landscapes that can adapt quickly to changing market dynamics. Finally, ongoing mergers and acquisitions are further challenging global IT solutions to remain agile and responsive.

While the drivers of change have evolved, the case for landscape consolidation remains strong ‚Äî especially when considering the transition to SAP S/4HANA as it presents a unique opportunity for enterprises to re-evaluate and modernize their environments. In the new cloud-first era, the key takeaway is that process harmonization alone is not sufficient. True transformation requires a commitment to standardizing on SAP best practices and processes. Only by combining harmonization with standardization can businesses fully realize the benefits of consolidation.

Landscape Options for SAP Process Harmonization

When consolidating SAP systems, organizations can choose among several landscape options that balance process harmonization with flexibility and deployment complexity. The Single Instance Strategy represents the highest degree of process harmonization, enforcing identical procedures and configurations globally within one system. The Virtual Single Instance Strategy, often called the full template approach, also targets global standardization but allows multiple production systems connected to a common template. This option achieves strong alignment across regions but requires significant upfront effort to harmonize processes and design a robust governance framework to maintain consistency.

In contrast, the Template + Multiple Development Systems Strategy (partial template) introduces a global development system for common configurations, while local development systems handle regional adaptations. This approach lowers harmonization effort but increases deployment and maintenance complexity, as changes must be coordinated and synchronized across environments. Finally, the Multiple Development Systems Strategy allows the greatest local flexibility but risks divergence without disciplined governance. Companies without adequate oversight often drift from standardized templates toward independent, inconsistent environments‚Äîundermining the benefits of consolidation.

Strong governance and well-defined change management are essential for success, regardless of the chosen model. SAP recommends establishing detailed governance and leveraging tools like SAP Solution Manager Cross-Landscape Distribution (XLD) to manage common configurations and automate object distribution.

Why Template Strategies are so Attractive

Template strategies are appealing because they balance the competing priorities of standardization and flexibility. While a fully harmonized, single global instance delivers high transparency, operational synergies, and seamless information sharing, it can also demand significant coordination and restrict local agility. Conversely, a highly decentralized landscape with multiple independent systems enables rapid local responses, minimizes coordination overhead, and preserves legacy practices‚Äîbut often sacrifices integration, efficiency, and visibility. In practice, the optimal point rarely lies at either extreme.

A well-governed global template represents the ‚Äúbest of both worlds.‚Äù It establishes common core processes and configurations across the enterprise, creating a unified baseline for reporting, governance, and automation, while still allowing local adaptations to meet regional or business-specific needs. This balance optimizes net benefits‚Äîachieving substantial harmonization without paralyzing flexibility. Organizations adopting this model can scale globally with consistency and efficiency, yet remain agile enough to evolve with market demands and regulatory changes.

Driving Alignment and Change Across the Enterprise

Consolidation initiatives only succeed when the business‚Äînot IT alone‚Äîowns the vision. CIOs and CFOs must jointly champion the strategy, aligning executive priorities and translating technical goals into tangible business outcomes. Indecision is worse than a decision; leaders must either commit fully to consolidation or abandon it. A half-hearted approach breeds confusion, wasted effort, and political resistance.

The business must first define why consolidation matters‚Äîwhether to streamline operations, reduce costs, or enable digital scalability‚Äîbefore any meaningful strategy discussions can occur. The opportunity cost of doing nothing far outweighs the risks of action. Inaction means missed chances for efficiency, growth, and long-term competitiveness. A strategic approach must therefore focus on optimizing performance through technology and process enhancements to achieve sustainable growth and market advantage.

Every consolidation journey ultimately aligns with one of three business scenarios. In the ‚ÄúWinner Takes It All‚Äù model, a larger entity absorbs a smaller one, prioritizing cost avoidance, risk reduction, and speed‚Äîoften driven by politics rather than process optimization. The ‚ÄúBest of Both Worlds‚Äù scenario emerges when merging entities are similar in size, each seeking to retain its systems and approaches, leading to cherry-picking, high complexity, and potential deadlock without decisive executive leadership. Lastly, the ‚ÄúCluster Selection‚Äù approach consolidates around relatively autonomous units, balancing flexibility and structure while reducing political tension. Each model carries trade-offs, but success in any of them depends on clear decision-making, consistent leadership, and an unwavering focus on the business rationale behind consolidation.

Decision-Making Framework: From Strategy to Execution

For complex organizations, making the right consolidation decisions can feel daunting. A structured, business-driven framework ensures that each decision is anchored in strategy, not convenience. Consolidation must begin with clarity on why a new landscape is required. The business must first define its objectives‚Äîwhether to improve visibility, reduce costs, or enable standardized global operations‚Äîand communicate the factors influencing consolidation to the IT organization. These include operational pain points, integration challenges, and the cultural readiness for adopting a global business model. Without this alignment and clear ownership, consolidation efforts risk becoming purely technical exercises detached from business value.

Once business intent is clear, IT and business leaders should collaboratively translate it into a practical landscape strategy and design. Together, they develop up to four viable landscape scenarios that reflect different balances of harmonization and flexibility. Each scenario is then assessed through an agreed-upon set of evaluation criteria‚Äîsuch as scalability, governance, deployment complexity, total cost of ownership, and change management impact‚Äîwith weighted importance assigned to both business and operational priorities. A structured decision process, often supported by workshops or governance boards, leads to a collective vote on the final landscape design and instance strategy. From there, a project roadmap can be established to guide execution. By following this disciplined approach, organizations ensure decisions are data-driven, collaborative, and sustainable‚Äîlaying the foundation for long-term enterprise value creation and true business-IT alignment.

Turning Consolidation into Competitive Advantage

The rise of SAP S/4HANA Cloud (Private and Public Editions), SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), and Business Data Cloud (BDC) has transformed how organizations approach landscape consolidation. These platforms provide the flexibility to run modern SAP systems across hybrid and multi-cloud environments, supported by AI-driven insights and automation.

SAP‚Äôs Business AI capabilities now automate repetitive tasks, predict trends, and enable intuitive, conversational interactions with business systems. By embedding intelligence directly into processes, organizations gain speed, accuracy, and foresight ‚Äî shifting their focus from data collection to decision-making.

SAP landscape consolidation is no longer a technical exercise ‚Äî it‚Äôs a strategic imperative for building an intelligent, agile enterprise. By harmonizing systems and processes, embracing cloud-native tools, and integrating AI, businesses position themselves for operational excellence and continuous innovation. In an era where speed and intelligence define market leaders, the organizations that master landscape consolidation today will define the intelligent enterprises of tomorrow.

Consider SAP Customer Advisory

If your organization is planning or evaluating an SAP instance strategy, our team at SAP Customer Advisory can help. We offer tailored guidance to align your architecture vision with business goals, accelerate transformation, and maximize value creation. Connect with me on LinkedIn to explore how we can shape your SAP strategy together.

Introduction

Solution Order is a business transaction in SAP Cloud ERP, used to sell solutions which can be a combination of either physical goods, one time services, recurring services, subscriptions, or projects bundled as one integrated customer offering. With the 2508 release of SAP Cloud ERP,  the OData V4 APIs for simulation of solution order is available. Simulation APIs can be used to simulate various entities of solution order without creating a solution order. Various determination logic like partner determination, price determination, billing plan etc can be simulated without creating a solution order. This can be used to provide a quote using a quoting engine outside of SAP Cloud ERP. Such external quoting solutions can benefit from the possibility of quoting a real time price calculated in SAP Cloud ERP using the Solution Order simulation APIs.  In this blog, you will find more information about the API, the entities available for consumption and the operations on these entities.

    }
  ]
}

You can also override a partner determined in simulation by passing the updated partner in the payload. This can be useful to for example simulate changes in shipping cost based on the address of a new partner that is passed which is different from the determined partner. 

POST <host> /sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_bussolnordsimulation/srvd_a2x/sap/bussolnordersimulation/0001
/BusinessSolutionOrder

X-CSRF-Token: abc

{
  "BusSolnOrdType": "SOLO",
  "BusSolnOrdDescription": "Simulation Demo",
  "SoldToParty": "17100001",
  "PayerParty": "17100001",
  "PaymentTerms": "0001",
  "SalesOrganization": "1710",
  "DistributionChannel": "10",
  "Division": "00",
  "RespEmployeeBusinessPartnerId": "9980000549",
  "_Item": [
    {
      "Product": "TG11",
      "Quantity": 1,
      "ShipToParty": "17100002",
      "BusSolnOrdItmQtyUnitISOCode": "PCE",
      
      "_Partner": [
        {
          "CustMgmtPartnerFunction": "00000055",
          "CustMgmtBusinessPartner": "17100002"
        }
      ]
    }
  ]
}

 

BusSolnOrdItmPriceElement ‚Äì Item Price Element

Similar to partners, You can pass an empty _PriceElement[] entity in the payload to read the item price elements that are calculated based on the pricing procedure assigned.

How ever you can also pass a new price element in simulation request like a discount to simulate the solution order with the discount condition

POST <host> /sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_bussolnordsimulation/srvd_a2x/sap/bussolnordersimulation/0001
/BusinessSolutionOrder

X-CSRF-Token: abc
{
  "BusSolnOrdType": "SOLO",
  "BusSolnOrdDescription": "Simulation Demo",
  "Language": "EN",
  "SoldToParty": "17100001",
  "SalesOrganization": "1710",
  "DistributionChannel": "10",
  "Division": "00",
  "RespEmployeeBusinessPartnerId": "9980000549",
  "_Item": [
    {
      "Product": "TG12",
      "Quantity": 1,
      "BusSolnOrdItmQtyUnitISOCode": "EA",
      
      //Adding a fixed discount
      "_PriceElement": [
        {
          "ConditionType": "DRV1",
          "ConditionRateValue": -10,
          "ConditionCurrency": "USD"
        }
      ]
    }
  ]
}

 

BusSolnOrdItmBillgReqItem ‚Äì Item Billing Request Item(Contract Item)

Billing Request Line item is relevant for a service contract item of type SOSC(Service Contract Item) and SOPA(Service Contract Item with Price Adaptation). You can simulate the billing plan by providing the billing date and settlement period in the payload and you will see the Billing Request Items accordingly. For example if you provide a settlement period as monthly for a contract running for 1 year, you will see 12 Billing Request Items in the simulation response.

POST <host> /sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_bussolnordsimulation/srvd_a2x/sap/bussolnordersimulation/0001
/BusinessSolutionOrder

{
  "BusSolnOrdType": "SOLO",
  "BusSolnOrdDescription": "Simulation of BRLs",
  "SoldToParty": "17100001",
  "SalesOrganization": "1710",
  "DistributionChannel": "10",
  "Division": "00",
  "RespEmployeeBusinessPartnerId": "9980000549",
  "_Item": [
    {
      "BusinessSolutionOrderItem": "10",
      "Product": "SRV_CONTRACT",
      "BusSolnOrdItmCategory": "SOSC",
      "Quantity": 1,
      "QuantityUnit": "AU",
      "BusSolnOrdItmQtyUnitISOCode": "C62",

      // Billing date first of the month
      "SrvcMgmtBillgPlanBillgDateRule": "BILL0002",
      // Settlement period - monthly billing
      "SettlementPeriodRule": "BILL0001",

      "ServiceContrItemStartDateTime": "2025-08-13T00:00:00Z",
      "ServiceContrItemEndDateTime": "2026-08-13T00:00:00Z",
      "_BillingRequestItem": [],
      "_PriceElement": []
    }
  ]
}

Introduction

Solution Order is a business transaction in SAP Cloud ERP, used to sell solutions which can be a combination of either physical goods, one time services, recurring services, subscriptions, or projects bundled as one integrated customer offering. With the 2508 release of SAP Cloud ERP, the OData V4 APIs for solution order is available. In this blog, you will find more information about the API, the entities available for consumption and the operations on these entities and some key differentiators of the V4 API. 

 

Authentication and Access

The communication arrangement with the Business Solution Order Integration scenario(SAP_COM_0706) needs to be in place to access the APIs. You will need to create a communication arrangement for the communication scenario SAP_COM_0706,  A Communication System with an inbound user. You can as well configure OAUTH 2.0 if needed.

The API allows Basic Authentication(Username/password), OAUTH2.0, and X.509 Certificate Authentication

 

Metadata

Metadata provides a description of the service, detailing the structure of the data, available entities, their properties, relationships, and supported operations. It acts as a blueprint that allows both developers and tools to understand how to interact with the service without needing prior knowledge of its design.

It can be accessed using the below URL

https://<<SERVER>>/sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_businesssolutionorder/srvd_a2x/sap/businesssolutionorder/0001/$metadata

Below is a screenshot, with a part of the metadata of the Business Solution Order API.

In the above partial view of the metadata, you can see the Entity BusinessSolutionOrder, it has key- BusinessSolutionOrder, and a set of properties like BusinesssSolutionOrder, BusSolnOrdType, BusSolnOrdDescription, etc. it also specifies the type, max length, precision etc of the property. There are a set of navigational properties(or associations) for the entity. Associations are other entities related to the current entity.

BusinessSolutionOrder ‚Äì Solution Order Header

With the Solution Order Header entity and its associations, you can create a solution order with the header and one or more of its associated entity(and its associated entities).

For Example: You can create a solution order by using the BusinessSolutionOrder along with Items, Partner, Item Partner, PriceElement, ItemRelationship, Text, UserStatus etc.

In the below example you will see creation of a solution order, adding items to the solution orders, creating a header text, and creating an item relationship between two items, all in separate OData calls and also to see how this can be achieved in one deep insert ODATA calls

Create a solution order with just header

POST <host>/sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_businesssolutionorder/srvd_a2x/sap/businesssolutionorder/0001
/BusinessSolutionOrder

X-CSRF-Token: abc

{
  "BusSolnOrdType": "SOLO",
  "BusSolnOrdDescription": "Solution Order",
  "Language": "EN",
  "SoldToParty": "17100001",
  "SalesOrganization": "1710",
  "DistributionChannel": "10",
  "Division": "00",
  "RespEmployeeBusinessPartnerId": "9980000549",
  "PurchaseOrderByCustomer": "External Reference"
}

 

Create an Item for an existing solution order

POST <host>/sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_businesssolutionorder/srvd_a2x/sap/businesssolutionorder/0001
/BusinessSolutionOrder/100004251/_Item

X-CSRF-Token: abc

{
  "Product": "TG11",
  "BusinessSolutionOrderItem": "10",
  "Quantity": 1,
  "QuantityUnit": "PC",
  "BusSolnOrdItmQtyUnitISOCode": "PCE"
}

 

Create another Item for an existing solution order

POST <host>/sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_businesssolutionorder/srvd_a2x/sap/businesssolutionorder/0001
/BusinessSolutionOrder/100004251/_Item

X-CSRF-Token: abc

{
  "Product": "SRV_01",
  "BusinessSolutionOrderItem": "20",
  "Quantity": 1,
  "SrvcContrDetnIsSpprsd": true,
  "QuantityUnit": "HR",
  "BusSolnOrdItmQtyUnitISOCode": "HUR"
}

 

Create a Header Text for an existing solution order

POST <host>/sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_businesssolutionorder/srvd_a2x/sap/businesssolutionorder/0001
/BusinessSolutionOrder/100004251/_Text

X-CSRF-Token: abc

{
  "TextObjectType": "0001",
  "Language": "EN",
  "BusinessSolutionOrderLongText": "This is a Header Note"
}

 

Create an item relationship between item 10 and item 20 of an existing solution order

POST <host>/sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_businesssolutionorder/srvd_a2x/sap/businesssolutionorder/0001
/BusinessSolutionOrder/100004251/_ItemRelationship

X-CSRF-Token: abc

{
  "BusinessSolutionOrder":"<<SOLUTION_ORDER_ID>>",
  "SrvcItemRelshpFromItemNumber": "10",
  "SrvcItemRelshpType": "001",
  "SrvcItemRelshpToItemNumber": "20"
}

 

You can also perform all the above in one deep insert OData request by specifying all the related entities in a single request

Create a solution order with deep insert: 2 items, override header partner, override item partner, add a header note and create an item relationship between item 10 and 20

POST <host>/sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_businesssolutionorder/srvd_a2x/sap/businesssolutionorder/0001
/BusinessSolutionOrder

X-CSRF-Token: abc

{
  "BusSolnOrdType": "SOLO",
  "BusSolnOrdDescription": "Solution Order",
  "Language": "EN",
  "SoldToParty": "17100001",
  "SalesOrganization": "1710",
  "DistributionChannel": "10",
  "Division": "00",
  "RespEmployeeBusinessPartnerId": "9980000549",
  "PurchaseOrderByCustomer": "External Reference",

  //Solution Order Item
  "_Item": [
    {
      "Product": "TG11",
      "BusinessSolutionOrderItem": "10",
      "Quantity": 1,
      "QuantityUnit": "PC",
      "BusSolnOrdItmQtyUnitISOCode": "PCE",
      "_Partner": [
        {
          "CustMgmtPartnerFunction": "00000055",
          "CustMgmtBusinessPartner": "17100003"
        }
      ]
    },
    {
      "Product": "SRV_01",
      "BusinessSolutionOrderItem": "20",
      "SrvcContrDetnIsSpprsd": true,
      "Quantity": 1,
      "QuantityUnit": "HR",
      "BusSolnOrdItmQtyUnitISOCode": "HUR"
    }
  ],

  //Partner at Header
  "_Partner": [
    {
      "CustMgmtPartnerFunction": "00000055",
      "CustMgmtBusinessPartner": "17100002"
    }
  ],

  //Notes at Header
  "_Text": [
    {
      "TextObjectType": "0001",
      "Language": "EN",
      "BusinessSolutionOrderLongText": "This is a Header Note"
    }
  ],

  //Relationship between Items
  "_ItemRelationship": [
    {
      "SrvcItemRelshpFromItemNumber": "10",
      "SrvcItemRelshpType": "001",
      "SrvcItemRelshpToItemNumber": "20"
    }
  ]
}

 

Read all the entities of a solution order

GET

GET
